review.title: Ontologies for the Integration of Air Quality Models and 3D City Models

metadata.title: Ontologies for the Integration of Air Quality Models and 3D City Models

sections.text: The holistic approach to sustainable urban planning implies the use of different models in an integrated manner that is capable of simulating the urban system. As linking such models is not a trivial task, one of the key elements that can be applied can be the description of the geometric characteristics of a city in an "interoperable" way. Concentrating on air quality as one of the most pronounced urban problems, the geometric aspects of a city can be described through objects such as those defined in CityGML, so that an appropriate air quality model can be applied to assess the quality of urban air based on atmospheric flow and chemical equations. It is generally accepted that an ontological approach can provide a general and robust way to link different models. However, a direct approach consisting of establishing correspondences between concepts is not sufficient in the current situation.

sections.heading: Keywords
sections.text: Ontology, 3D city model, air quality model, street canyon model, sustainable urban planning

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Sustainable development and urban planning One of the most frequently cited definitions of sustainability is the one drawn up by the Brundtland Commission in its report (Brundtland, 1987), which defines sustainable development as development that "responds to the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs." The report highlights three fundamental components of sustainable development: environmental protection, economic growth and social justice. Whether environmental issues are not the only aspects of sustainable planning and decision-making processes, they are impossible to avoid. In urban areas, one of the most important environmental problems is air pollution, which is largely caused by car traffic. This pollution can cause serious damage to health and is of particular importance due to the high population density in cities. Improving air quality is therefore imperative and must be taken into account in a sustainable urban planning process. In fact, a deep understanding and accurate prediction of urban flow and pollutant dispersion in cities is required to carry out proactive urban planning.

sections.heading: Air quality models
sections.text: The various categories include 3D air pollution models, which aim to "reconstruct" the environment, its properties and physical laws. Current air quality models and the associated simulation systems apply a number of (simplistic) assumptions about the environment, in particular its geometry and physical properties, depending on the scale of interest. Therefore, models used to study air quality at the local to regional level use a spatial resolution on a grid basis, where each grid cell has dimensions in the order of 1 x 1 km. To return to the urban scale, simulation models attempt to reconstruct the building shapes and basic geometric features and dimensions in order to improve simulation results.

sections.heading: 3D city models
sections.text: At the same time, 3D city models are evolving rapidly (some cities have already been modelled in CityGML), which may (in part) provide the air quality models with the missing information they need to be more precise and effective. On the other hand, urban planners and stakeholders need information on the impact of their development plans on air quality development (current air quality and future scenarios), so their models need to be supplemented by data from air quality models. However, this data does not fit directly into the urban planning models, but needs to be adapted to these models (aggregated, calculated, etc.).

sections.heading: 2. CityGML
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: What is CityGML?
sections.text: CityGML is an open information model for the representation and exchange of 3D virtual city models at the international level (OGC, 2006) (Kolbe et al, 2005) (Kolbe et al, 2006).CityGML defines the classes and relationships for the most relevant topographic objects in cities and regional models in terms of their geometric, topological, semantic and optical characteristics. It has been defined in this way because purely graphic or geometric 3D models are not sufficient for visualization purposes, for applications such as urban and landscape planning, architectural design, tourist and leisure activities, 3D cadastral, environmental simulations, mobile telecommunications, disaster management, homeland security, vehicle and pedestrian navigation, training simulators or mobile robotics. CityGML distinguishes five successive detailed levels (LOD), from terrain alone to architectural models (exterior and interior).

sections.heading: Underlying concepts of CityGML
sections.text: The most important topics are: - terrain (called relief), - coverage by land use objects (called land use), - transport (both graph structures and 3D surface data), - vegetation (solitary objects, surfaces and volumes, with vegetation classification), - water objects (volumes and surfaces), - locations, in particular buildings (bridge, tunnel, excavation or embankment in the vicinity), - urban furniture (for immovable objects such as traffic lights, traffic signs, benches or bus stops). Thus, the basic concepts of CityGML (see figure below) are: relief, land use, location, buildings (as a subconcept of location), transport object, vegetation object, water object, urban furniture. Buildings in CityGML can be represented with roofs, walls, doors, rooms and even furniture (according to LOD), which are represented with relief objects, surface objects, surface objects, surface objects (water object, surface objects, LOD), surface objects (water object, surface objects, surface objects, LOD).

sections.heading: 3. OUPP: an ontology of urban planning
sections.text: CityGML, with its urban and geometric concepts and their semantic relationships, is useful to represent an urban planning project, but not sufficient. In fact, some non-geometric concepts such as right of way or more abstract concepts such as soft mobility are missing in CityGML. OUPP has been defined and is still under development within the framework of the research project "Integrating Urban Knowledge into 3D City Models," which is funded by the Swiss Confederation and part of the European COST action "Towntology." The main objective of this research is to contribute to better communication between the various stakeholders involved in an urban planning process. The main sources for OUPP are master and local plans (such as PLQ) as well as GIS data from Geneva.

sections.heading: 4. Air quality models
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: The aims of air quality models
sections.text: Since air pollution causes damage to people, vegetation and ecosystems, reducing emissions of pollutants into the atmosphere is essential. Models for the propagation, transport and conversion of air pollutants have been defined, which are used to support such reductions and, more generally, to support environmental decisions.

sections.heading: The diversity of air quality models
sections.text: According to (Moussiopoulos et al 2006), models describing the distribution and transport of air pollutants in the atmosphere can be distinguished in many ways, such as: - the spatial scale (global; regional-continental; local-regional; local-dry; local), - the time scale (episodic models, (statistical) long-term models), - the treatment of traffic equations (Euler models, Lagranger models), - the treatment of various processes (chemistry, wet and dry deposition) - the complexity of the approach. sections.heading: 5. Towards an ontology of air quality models
sections.text: The first phase of our ontology of air quality models focuses on road canyon models. The underlying concepts and properties of road canyon models are based on equations that serve as input: - the properties of the pollutant source (source location, product emitted, etc.) - the meteorological conditions, mainly the wind conditions in the environment (speed, direction in relation to the road canyon, etc.), but also to a certain extent the thermal conditions (solar heating) - the road canyon geometry, especially its aspect ratios (height-width ratio for 2D and 3D models, height-length ratio for 3D models) or its orientation in relation to the ambient wind and production as output: - a flow characterized mainly by its vortices (intensity, direction of rotation, location, etc.) - a pollutant dispersion distribution between the two areas.

sections.heading: 6. Interconnecting CityGML and air quality models
sections.text: In this section, we will present different integration patterns that occur when CityGML (CG) and an air quality model (AQ) are connected and how they are represented in the OUPP ontology. Our goal is to provide a formal (logical) description of the linkages at the conceptual level that can be easily converted into an automated (computer-aided) process. The main idea is to create "associative" concepts and axioms in OUPP that relate to the interconnected concepts in AQ and CG. The goal is 1. to depict potentially complex integration patterns 2. to place and avoid all integration-related units in OUPP, to modify AQ orCG 3. to provide a kind of centralized intermediary for the integration of other models (water quality, noise reduction, etc.) The linkage technique that we propose here is inspired by the work of Mitra, Re-hold and Ontussiologies that are not related to the articulations in their architecture.

sections.heading: Interconnection patterns
sections.text: 0. Property ranges The simple interconnection pattern occurs when one property of a concept in one ontology has its area in the other ontology. For example, the geometric property of an isosurface in AQ is a surface defined in CG. In this situation, it is not necessary to define an interconnection concept.

sections.heading: 1. Concepts with different viewpoints
sections.text: The properties of the two concepts are not the same in both ontologies, and some properties can be calculated from those of the other ontology. For example, the road in AQ has a latitude property, while the road in CG has a geometry. Furthermore, the width in AQ can be derived from the geometry in CG. We present the following connecting concept (concepts of the same name differ in that they are preceded by the ontology name).

sections.heading: OUPP:street
sections.text: Properties in _ AQ a AQ: street in _ CG a CG: street Each instance of OUPP: street refers to the same street in AQ and CG.The following axiom expresses the dependence between the properties of width and geometry for all in OUPP: street: s.in _ AQ.width = width _ computation (s.in _ CG.geometry), where width _ computation represents the (possibly complex) geometric function that calculates the width of the polygon that forms the road geometry in CG. Another similar example is AQ: building, whose roof pitch is calculated from the roof surface of CG: building and its albedo derived from the surfaces, material and color of CG: building.

sections.heading: 2. Instances derived from several instances in the other ontology
sections.text: This is a more complex integration pattern in which one conceptual instance in one ontology corresponds to a series of conceptual instances in the other. For example, a street canyon (in AQ) only exists if there is a street (in CG) delimited by buildings in a specific configuration.

The following axiom defines the term street canyon for all c in OUPP: street _ canyon: for all x in c.buildings _ 1: borders (x, s) and for all y in c.buildings _ 2: borders (y, s) and continuously _ aligned (c.buildings _ 1) and continuously _ aligned (c.buildings _ 2) where borders and continuously _ aligned are geometric predictions. Furthermore, the properties of the street canyon in AQ depend on its components (in CG) properties (as in case 1) and possibly on other factors.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion and future work
sections.text: In this paper, we have argued that integrating air quality models with 3D city models can significantly improve air quality modelling and sustainable urban planning. Air quality modelling can then leverage the semantically rich representations of 3D city models to facilitate the simulation of air flows. We have proposed a theoretical and practical approach to air quality and 3D city model integration based on the definition of an ontology of air quality and the use of an ontology of the urban planning process that acts as an intermediary to help urban planners deal with air pollution issues. We have proposed a theoretical and practical approach to air quality and 3D city model integration that is based on the definition of an ontology of air quality and the use of an ontology of the urban planning process that acts as an intermediary. By this approach, it is possible to support and formally specify complex linkage patterns. In addition, we can re-use the OUPP mediation sontology to integrate several other models that are of sustainable urban planning interest and we plan for the near future in this air quality model and incorporate the results from other examples.

metadata.abstractText: In the perspective of a sustainable urban planning, it is necessary to investigate cities in a holistic way and to accept surprises in the response of urban environments to a particular set of strategies. For example, the process of inner-city densification may limit air pollution, carbon emissions, and energy use through reduced transportation; on the other hand, the resulting street canyons could lead to local levels of pollution that could be higher than in a low-density urban setting. The holistic approach to sustainable urban planning implies using different models in an integrated way that is capable of simulating the urban system. As the interconnection of such models is not a trivial task, one of the key elements that may be applied is the description of the urban geometric properties in an “interoperable” way. Focusing on air quality as one of the most pronounced urban problems, the geometric aspects of a city may be described by objects such as those defined in CityGML, so that an appropriate air quality model can be applied for estimating the quality of the urban air on the basis of atmospheric flow and chemistry equations. It is generally admitted that an ontology-based approach can provide a generic and robust way to interconnect different models. However, a direct approach, that consists in establishing correspondences between concepts, is not sufficient in the present situation. One has to take into account, among other things, the computations involved in the correspondences between concepts. In this paper we first present theoretical background and motivations for the interconnection of 3D city models and other models related to sustainable development and urban planning. Then we present a practical experiment based on the interconnection of CityGML with an air quality model. Our approach is based on the creation of an ontology of air quality models and on the extension of an ontology of urban planning process (OUPP) that acts as an ontology mediator.
